The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONORABLE SIR ROBERT Nanton, Knight, chiefe Secretary to his Maie≈øties ≈øtate and one of his Maie≈øties mo≈øt Honorable Priuie Councell.
div.p:
HE that hath pa≈ø≈øed a dangerous ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, and hath recouered his former health againe, is bound in a double Obligation: The one is to bee gratefull to the Per≈øon by who≈øe meanes he recouered his health: The other is to v≈øe all meanes po≈øsible, that tho≈øe which be ≈øick of the like di≈øea≈øe, may by his recouery be the better: According to that of our Sauior, Et tu coÃÑuer≈øus confirma fratres tuos: And therefore right Honourable, although it be ≈øomewhat be≈øides cu≈øtome to make Dedications of printed Sermons; yet it is my duty to offer to your Honour the fir≈øt fruits of my conuer≈øion: Your Honor being next and immediately vnder God the chiefe worker thereof. The which as it is a gretaer benefite then any worldly thing can afford me, ≈øo doth it require a fuller acknowledgement then as yet, I could at any time manife≈øt: how≈øoeuer I haue mo≈øt earne≈øtly de≈øiredit. In which re≈øpect being ouer intreated by ≈øome of my friends to publi≈øh this Sermon of my Recantation, and to ≈øet downe to the open view of all, the
iu≈øt rea≈øons, and ≈øollid grounds that moued mee there unto. I haue made hold to pa≈ø≈øe it vnder your Honours name, hoping by your former encouragements, of your loning acceplance. And albeit they be but my fir≈øt A≈ø≈øayes in this kind, and therefore may chance to ≈øeem: but har≈øh, yet becau≈øe my de≈øire is only to ≈øet forth God; mercy towards me: your Honors louing kindne≈ø≈øe ≈øhewed to me, And to ≈øtop the mouthes of ≈øome malicious Papi≈øts that rayle again≈øt me, I tru≈øt that your Honour will accept of this my weake endeauour as a token of my thankefull mind, which I in all duty recommend vnto your Honours fauour, and your ≈øelfe and yours, in your affaires vnto the mercy, and bli≈ø≈øe of the ble≈ø≈øed Trinity, who ever ≈øo a≈øs≈øi≈øt your Honour in all your proceedings, as that after the≈øe pre≈øent toyles and troubles, your Honor may receine that happy Crowne of glory, Quam repromi≈øcit Deus diligentibus ≈øe.

q.hi: It is good for me that I have beene in trouble, for thereby I have learned thy Statutes.

div.p:
De elementiaad Neronem.
SEneca a graue Phylo≈øopher, writing vnto Nero, and tracting of Cinna an ancient Roman, and publike Rebell, hee v≈øeth the≈øe words: Periti medici vbi blanda medela non pracedat tentant contrarium. It is the v≈øe of good Phy≈øicians that when a gentle Meditine doth take no place, they pre≈øently apply a ≈øharper ≈øalue, and more bitter corra≈øiue: The like cour≈øe taketh Almighty God with tho≈øe that bee repugnant vnto his holy will and rebellious again≈øt his knowne truth, when faire meanes and louing kindnes cannot preuaile, then goeth he non alliciendo ≈øed compellendo, not by alluring or enticing, them but by compelling and enforcing them, vt quod non po≈øsit per di≈øceptatione
≈øaltem po≈ø sit per vim, that tho≈øe whom hee cannot win by louing exhortations he will bring them home by extremities: For as I≈øocrates an ancient Grecian ≈øaith, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , afflictions are our in≈øtructions, and extremitie is Gods opportunity. The prodigal child would not returne vn-his father vntill extremity compelled him, Mana≈ø≈øes liuing in his pompe and plea≈øure in Ieru≈øalem, planted groues, and ≈øet vp Idols again≈øt God and godline≈ø≈øe, but being in pri≈øon in Babilon, and chained in a dungeon the Scripture ≈øaith, that he did turne his heart vnto the Lord his God and be≈øought him earne≈øtly: therefore ≈øaith Salomon to all things, there is an appointed time, and a time for euery purpo≈øe vnder the heaueÃÑs: God hath his time to afflict vs, that we may the more earne≈øtly ≈øeeke after him, multiplicatae ≈øunt infirmitates, eorum po≈øtea acclerauerme: as our Sauiour ≈øaith, ≈øeeke and you ≈øhall find? But how mu≈øt we ≈øeek? it is ≈øaid we mu≈øt ≈øeeke him by Prayer. Inuoca me in die tribulationis & ego exaudiam te, call vpon me in the time of trouble, and I will heare thee.

The Prophet Dauid being much afflicted in many of his P≈øalmes, doth often call vpon the Lord, as in the 120. P≈øalme ad Dominum cum tribularer clamaui: when I was in trouble I called vppon the Lord, and in the 130. P≈øalme, de profundis clamaui ad te domini, domine exaudi vocem meam, out of the deepe of my heart haue I called vnto thee O Lord, O Lord heare my prayer: ≈øo that as pro≈øperity doth cau≈øe many to forget God, and to neglect their duties towards him: ≈øo doth aduer≈øity call them home againe, and makes them more carefull to ≈øeeke after him, and to walke more warily in his wayes. And therefore, the Prophet Dauid in another place of this P≈øalme ≈øaith, Before I was in trouble I went wrong, but now haue I learned to keep thy lawes, and ≈øo concludeth in the ≈øeuenth ver≈øe ≈øaying, bonuÃÑ e≈øt mihi quia bumili a≈øti me, it is
good for me that I haue beene in trouble. The like may I ≈øay at this time right Wor≈øhipfull and my louing auditors, it was good for mee that I haue beene in trouble, for before I was in trouble albeit I had a zeale to ≈øerue the Lord, yet I had not the true way and meanes to ≈øerue him as he ought to be ≈øerued: hauing liued as long time from the truth as from my country and friends, being from my fir≈øt arriuall into this Land, deteyned in pry≈øon, ≈øeque≈øtred from all conuer≈øation and ≈øociety. In this my affliction and long mi≈øery I prayed both in≈øtantly and feruently to the Almighty that hee would vouhc≈øafe to open mine eyes, enlighten my darkenes, and incline my heart vnto his te≈øtimonies, that I might ≈øerue him in holine≈ø≈øe and righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe all the dayes of my life, for in him only, and for him only, I de≈øired to liue and dye, refoluing my ≈øelfe that what≈øoeuer ≈øhall bee fall me in this life, I will e≈øteeme it all happine≈ø≈øe, for the peace of con≈øcience and the glory of Gods mo≈øt holy name.

As I was thus communing with my ≈øoule, there came into my mind that worthy precept of St. Iohn when he ≈øaith, Tru≈øt not euery Spirit, but try the Spirits, whether they bee of God or no: Likewi≈øe I did much ruminate and ponder with my ≈øelfe, the place of the Prophet E≈øay, where he ≈øaith; to the Law and the Te≈øtimony If they ≈øpeake not according to this Word, It is becau≈øe there is no light in them. Whence I did gather, that all Seruices and Doctrines of Religion are not acceptable before God: For Faith commeth by hearing and hearing of the word of God: ≈øo that if they ≈øpeake not according to this Word it is rather fancy, then faith, humane traditions, then Gods in≈øtitutions, and con≈øequently condemned by our Sauiour in the 15. of Mathew, where he expre≈øly reprooued the Commandements and traditions of men. And St. Paul reiecteth as Ba≈øtard ≈ølippes all voluntary Seruices
what apparance or outward ≈øhew of deuotion ≈øoeuer they beare.

By which and other like places, I was moued to examine my profe≈øsion whether it were of Gods in≈øtitution, and e≈øpeciall command ≈øpecified to vs, or whether God were the author of tho≈øe Seruices and Ceremonies which now beate great ≈øway in the Church of Rome: and after due examination I found out for certaine that many points of the Religion, now embraced by the Romani≈øts are not to be found within the volume of Gods Word. When I con≈øidered this, and perceiued the weakenes of the grounds that mu≈øt warrant our ≈øoules, it gaue me occa≈øion to for≈øake my communion with the Church of Rome, in who≈øe bo≈øome I haue beene long detayned; of whom I may iu≈øtly complaine as the Prophet Ieremy did of the fal≈øe teachers in his dayes, they haue reiected the Word of the Lord, and what wi≈øedome is then in them.

Likewi≈øe I often bu≈øied my ≈øelfe in reading of Books, treating of Religion, & ≈øuch as handled matters now in controuer≈øie: as the Apollogy of the mo≈øt reuerent Father and learned Scholler Iohn Iewell, Bi≈øhop of Sari≈øbury, written again≈øt a friend and neere Ki≈øeman of mine Docter Harding; together with another no le≈ø≈øe reuerent then learned, Marcus Antoniuus de dominis Archbi≈øhop of Spalato, whom after I had well peru≈øed, I found ≈øuch comfort in my con≈øcience and ≈øuch ≈øollid doctrine for my ≈øoule, that I made no doubt to ≈øay with the Prophet Dauid, a domino factum e≈øt hoc, this is the Lords doing. Now the Sunne is vp, and the Clouds of ignorance are gone, the truth ≈øhineth, and the Kingdome of Heauen is at hand, therfore I may ≈øay with my Text, bonum e≈øt mihi quia humilia≈øtime. It is good for mee that I was in trouble, for thereby I haue learned thy Statutes. But what
are the≈øe Statutes? they are the Word of God, contayned in the Law and the Prophets: which are the rule of our Life, and the ≈øquare of our Faith, and the very Oracle of Almighty God, from Heauen to reueale his will vnto vs, for certaine it is that Chri≈øt came not to de≈øtroy the Law, but to fulfill it: hee ≈øwarued not from the Law and the Prophets, neither did the Apo≈øtles teach any thing vpon their owne will and di≈øcretion, but the Doctrine which they receiued of Chri≈øt, they faithfully deliuered it vnto the people, and Nations.

And this they preached at the fir≈øt in viua voce:, that is, in a liuely Voyce, and afterward deliuered it vnto vs in writing, to be the foundation and Pillar of our Faith, Qui hoc credit (≈øaith Tertullian) nihil habet quod vitra credat: He that beleeueth this, hath no Obligation to beleeue any thing el≈øe: and this is that which we ought to beleeue without either adding or dimini≈øhing.

I would now demand of the Pope and his Papalins, in what Go≈øpell, in what Apo≈øtle, in what Prophet or Euangeli≈øt, or Book of Mo≈øes, they find either Pope or his ≈øupremacy? where are his Pardons? where is his Ma≈ø≈øe? where Images? together with many other his Fopperies, which now they hold to be very precious. We reade in the 20. of Exodus, that almighty God doth expre≈øly forbid the making of any Image, to repre≈øent the Per≈øon of Almighty God, or to do any ≈øeruice and obey ≈øance to any Picture, or repre≈øentation of the creature: for fir≈øt God is a Spirit invi≈øible, incomprehen≈øible, and Eternall, and therefore hee cannot be ≈øignified by any Image or creature, which is both corporall and momentary, and therefore God in his ≈øecond Commandement forbiddeth all ≈øeruice done vnto Images: but contrary vnto this the Church of Rome doth command
and allow not only the making of Images, but al≈øo doth command the ≈øeruing and wor≈øhipping of them, as by incen≈øing them, in lighting of Candles vnto them, by kneeling before them, and by yeelding vp their offrings, and deuotions vnto them.

All which can bee no le≈ø≈øe then gro≈ø≈øe Idolatry: for albeit, they do not wor≈øhip their Images, as ≈øtocks and ≈øtones, but as they repre≈øent either God or ≈øome Saint: So likewi≈øe did not the I≈øralits, wor≈øhip their golden Calfe, as the true God, but they did wor≈øhip the true God in the Calfe, and yet notwith≈øtanding, the Text ≈øaith, that they did commit Idolatry, and many of them were ≈øeuerely puni≈øhed for the ≈øame, Exod. 32. ≈øo that the Idolatry of the Church of Rome is as gro≈ø≈øe as that of the I≈øralites. What can bee more iniutious vnto God then to hope for helpe of him, and yet notwith≈øtanding to pray vnto a ≈øencele≈ø≈øe ≈øtock? The faith of the Patriarkes and Prophets, & righteous Fathers from the beginning of the world, was the ≈øame as ours is, and ought to be, as the Apo≈øtle ≈øaith, that they were all baptized in the red Sea, and did eate the ≈øame ≈øpirituall meate, and iniutious vnto drinke the ≈øame ≈øpirituall drinke, as wee doe now: But was Abraham, I≈øaack, or Iaacob, Papi≈øts? did they fall downe before ≈øtocks and ≈øtones? before Idols or Images to pray or offer vnto them? did they go on pilgrimage one to anothers Relikes to doe deuotion vnto them? there is neither ≈øhew nor ≈øhadow of the≈øe things in the Word of God.
Chry≈øo≈øtome ≈øaith, that Chri≈øt, nee di≈øce≈øsit a lege neque a Prophetis: but none of all this is to bee found in the Law or the Prophets, therefore in no wi≈øe to bee admitted.

As touching the di≈øtinction which they v≈øe betwixt Duleiam and Latreiam, affirming that they giue to Saints
onely Du ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ iam; that is, a kind of Religious Seruice, and that they giue Latreiam vnto Almighty God, intimating thereby that they both wor≈øhip God and ≈øerue their Images: Our Sauiour confoundeth them in the 4, of Mathew ≈øaying as is written, Thou ≈øhalt wor≈øhip the Lord thy God, and him only ≈øhalt thou ≈øerue.

And Saint Paul per≈øwadeth the Corinthians to turne from Idols and Images, and to ≈øerue the euerliuing God, where hee doth v≈øe the word Duliea, for the Seruice of the true God, ≈øhewing heereby the oppo≈øition that is betwixt the one and the other, that he that ≈øerueth Images, cannot in any wi≈øe ≈øerue the Almighty God:yea God him≈øelf ≈øpeaketh it plainely, in his fir≈øt Commandement, to wor≈øhip and ≈øerue him, only, neither will he giue his Honour to any other.

In the fir≈øt precept God condemneth all fal≈øe Gods, in the ≈øecond all fal≈øe wor≈øhiping, of the true God, as making of Images vnto God, or yeelding vnto the Image any part of deuotion which belongeth vnto the Lord. For it is not enough to know the true God, and to acknowledge him alone to be wor≈øhipped, according to the fir≈øt Commandement, & yet breake the 2. by wor≈øhipping him ami≈ø≈øe: As in ≈øetting vp of Images, and bowing and kneeling vnto theÃÑ: for as the Almighty God ≈øaith in the 27. of Deut. ver≈øe 15 Cur≈øed be the man that ≈øhall make any carued or molten Image, for it is abomination vnto the Lord, they that make them are like vnto them, and ≈øo are all they that put their tru≈øt in them. For as Nadab and Abihu, the ≈øonnes of Aaron by offring of ≈øtrange fire before the Lord, became lyable to his wrath and maledictioÃÑ for their pre≈øumption: ≈øo the Papi≈øts that doe adde ≈øtrange doctrines and new inuented traditions to the Word of God,
and ≈øeruice of the Lord do incurre his heauy wrath & continuall di≈øplea≈øure. And therfore we are willed by the holy Gho≈øt to flye from them and their abhominations, lea≈øt we be partakers of their ≈øinne, end ≈øo likewi≈øe of their puni≈øhment,

The 2. Motiue that moued me to leaue the Papi≈øts, is, becau≈øe they do as it were hood-winke the people in their religion, giuing a Seruice in a language they vnder≈øtand not, amazing them with many outward Ornaments, and huge heapes of Ceremonies, calling Ignorance the the Mother of Deuotion, and Images Layemens Books. But we reade in the Councell of Tolledo in Spaine, that Ignorantia e≈øt mater omnium errorum, Ignorance is the mother of Deuotion, but rather of Athei≈øme, and the roote of all errour. What ≈øhould it auaile Mo≈øes to ≈øpeake in Hehrew to a man of Africa, who vnder≈øtands no Hebrew, and what may it auaile the people of other countries to heare their common Seruice in a tongue they vnder≈øtand not: for albeit they heare with their eares, they vnder≈øtand not with their hearts, they are not much better then Birds and Parrats which babble much, and vnder≈øtand nothing: Therefore in the primatiue Church; when Faith was then in learning, the prayers & other Seruice was ≈øet fourth in a common tongue, knowne vnto the people that they might vnder≈øtand what they did profe≈ø≈øe, and to be able to giue a rea≈øon of their faith.

When Almighty God appointed Mo≈øes to open the Law for the direction of his Church, he decreed it as an euerla≈øting duty to all his people, that the booke of the Law ≈øhold not depart out of their mouthes, but that they ≈øhould meditate therein day and night, to ob≈øerue and doe according to all that is written: But how ≈øhould they meditate in them if they be vnknown to them? and how ≈øhould they
know theÃÑ if they be in a tongue they vnder≈øtand not? is not this the cur≈øe which God by his Prophet denounceth ≈øaying, I wil ≈øpeak vnto this people in another language & by ≈øtraÃÑge lips, ≈øo as they ≈øhal not vnder≈øtand me: who would not iu≈øtly ≈øu≈øpect ≈øuch a church, yea & coÃÑdemn it, wheÃÑ to maintain and continue their errour, they will haue none of the people either to ≈øearch the Scriptures, or to vnder≈øtand their common Seruice that they heare dayly? Thus the ≈øilly Papalins are led like blinde men they know not whether, and with her fides implicita that is, to beleeue in gro≈ø≈øe (for their part) they know not what are lamentably ≈øeduced. The people go to ≈øee Ma≈ø≈øe, but not to vnder≈øtand it; and ofttimes the Prie≈øt him≈øelfe vnder≈øtands not what he ≈øaith, and this is done for a double end, the one is that the people may be kept ≈øtill in Ignorance, and the other is, that it may bee a marke of the Popes dominion, in that they v≈øe his language in their deuine Seruice, and ≈øo might bee thought to hold their Religion from the Popes Chaire, euen as the Spaniard con≈øtreyneth the Indians to ≈øpeake Spani≈øh, the better to reduce them vnder his Dominion. But the Prophet Dauid ≈øaith P≈øal. 86. Dominus narauit in Scriptur is populoruÃÑ, God hath opened and declared his wayes and will in the Scriptures: but in who≈øe Scriptures? Hierom vpon this place an≈øwereth thus, the Scriptures of the people, ≈øo called, becau≈øe they be read vnto the people, that is to ≈øay, that all may vnder≈øtand, becau≈øe the Princes of Chri≈øt which were the Apo≈øtles and Euangeli≈øts did not write them for afew, but for the whole people, not that afew, but that all ≈øhould vnder≈øtand.
